content.rendered:
The Portamento​ effect refers to the effect of gliding a note at one pitch into another note at a different pitch, between any two audio signals, an effect creatable only by instruments including the human voice. For researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, a colossal feat has been achieved by creating the portamento effect in real-time with the help of an algorithm that uses just math, to blend the musical notes seamlessly.

This work of an MIT student, Trevor Henderson, now a graduate student in computer science, relies on ‘Optimal Transport’, a geometry-based framework that determines the most efficient ways to move objects, or data points, between multiple origins and destination configurations, to create the Portamento effect. Henderson’s paper describing the algorithm has not only won the ‘best student paper’ award at the recent International Conference on Digital Audio Effects, it’s algorithm has flawlessly merged various audio clips, such as a piano note gliding into a human voice, and a song blending into another song. For Henderson, a classically trained organist, who performs electronic music and has been a DJ on MIT’s radio station, this wasn’t too much of a stretch. “When I see a new idea, I ask, ‘Is this applicable to music?’” he says. In work that originated in a class project, it was a triumphant undertaking that he himself came to use to build his own equipments to smoothly transition between songs, on his radio show. Trevor Henderson was aided by Justin Soloman, an X-Consortium Career Development Assistant Professor in the Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, and also an aesthete cello and piano player.

The applications of optimal transport include supply chains, fluid dynamics, image alignment, 3-D modelling, computer graphics, and more. In computer graphics, one of the ways optimal transport in the algorithm is used is to transform shapes by finding the optimal movement from each point on one shape into another. In addition to this, concepts of signal processing were used too. Musical instruments produce sound through the vibrations of components, like, violin uses strings. These vibrations are captured as audio signals, where the frequency and amplitude represent different pitches. Conventionally, in this theory, it is done with a fade, that is, one signal is reduced in volume while the other rises. On the other hand, Henderson’s algorithm smoothly slides frequency segments from one clip into another, with no fading effect. To do so, the algorithm splits any two audio clips into segments of 50 milliseconds. Then, a Fourier Transform is run, which converts the two segments into their frequency components, which are then lumped together into individual ‘notes’. Then an ‘interpolation parameter’ comes into play, which determines where each note will be on its path, stitching the two signals from starting of one signal to the end of the other signal, thus creating the Portamento effect.

Believably, the algorithm when embedded into equipments could be used by DJs to transition between tracks, and also by musicians and beat boxers who might use it blend instruments and voice in studios.

Snigdha Lokre

EC 4th Sem

For researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, a colossal feat has been achieved by creating the portamento effect […]

content.rendered:
It’s a cold winter day. You pick up a cup of steaming hot coffee, but you can’t feel its cosy warmth. You are covered tightly by your blanket but you can’t feel its furry softness. Imagine shaking someone’s hands but not being able to feel the gentle warmth that comes with it. In our daily lives, being able to feel these things is taken for granted. Unfortunately, people with hand amputations have to rely on prosthetics. Though it restores their mobility, prosthetic hands lack the sensory perceptions that are crucial in most activities. Hence, people taking the aid of prosthetics face arduous daily life and social challenges. These problems result in psychological problems like isolation, depression and even suicidal thoughts.

Existing technology uses the help of stretchable electronics to integrate sensory data into prosthetics, but challenges in geometric complexity have resulted in unsatisfactory results. To overcome this problem, researchers at Purdue university, Georgia, have developed a flexible and stretchable electronic glove that can fit on a prosthetic arm easily. The glove reacts to external stimuli like temperature, pressure and humidity. It provides mechanical softness and sensory perception. Furthermore, it replicates the appearance of a human hand and hence, it gives way to seamless physical interaction. Things just got real!

This electronic glove or e-glove is nitrile based. Initially, it is layered with epoxy and conductive silver ink is printed on its surface. Active sensing elements are distributed uniformly over the globe through sequential transfer printing to provide sensory information. To secure the bonds, the glove is put in an oven at 70 degrees Celsius for two hours. This process is repeated several times to form multiple layers consisting of different sensors. Finally, the entire structure is dip-coated in an uncured silicone elastomer to form the outermost layer- the skin. The silicon layer consists of a skin colourant to give a human-like appearance. The glove is accompanied by a specially designed wristwatch for displaying sensory data and transmitting it. To top it all off, the entire process uses cost-effective technologies to minimize initial and maintenance expenses.

Touch is one of our five senses. It is equally as important as seeing, hearing or speaking. Touch is crucial for survival and the lack of it results in a multitude of problems and challenges. For most of us, being able to feel is a part of our ordinary lives and we take it for granted. One can only recognize its significance if they lack it. This electronic glove bridges the gap between prosthetics and real arms. It provides a way for people with amputations to interact like ordinary people and feel complete again. This glove makes prosthetics better than ever before and is a surefire way to change lives.

Khadija Sidhpuri

CE 4th Sem

Imagine shaking someone’s hands but not being able to feel the gentle warmth that comes with it. In our daily […]

content.rendered:
We all know water is a universal solvent and nothing can stop its flow. Not even the large rocks. It can easily seep through surfaces. That is the reason most of the medicinal drugs are supplied to our body in a water solution. What if the drugs can be provided faster to the affected area than an injection or oral intake? Ever wondered water trespassing the surface at a speed double than cheetah’s speed. The transport of water droplets at the nanoscale allows us to do so without expending any energy. This can help us to solve our day to day life problems in better and efficient ways.

Ermioni Papadopoulou and Petros Koumoutsakos at ETH Zürich, Constantine Megaridis at the University of Illinois at Chicago, and Jens Walther at the Technical University of Denmark have proved how water droplets can move so much faster at the nanoscale. According to them, simply patterning the graphene will let the water droplets flow through its layer at very high speed without expending energy to pump the water through it. The mode of transport is completely different than we see in our day to day life. To create the wettability gradients; ranging from hydrophobic to hydrophilic; graphene surfaces were structurally patterned. Then on the surface water nanodroplets were placed. On the hydrophilic domain, larger contact angles were created and on hydrophobic domains, smaller contact angles were created due to different surface patterns. The forward acceleration of droplets was due to the difference at the advancing and receding end of the water droplets. In the experiment, they observed the velocity of droplets in the order of 100 meters per second. As usual, larger droplets moved slower than the smaller ones due to their inertia and greater friction with the surface.

After studying the transport mechanism of these droplets, they developed a model to predict the trajectory of the droplets based on the scaling law derived by them. According to them, this can be very useful in heat dissipation for nanoscale and microscale systems, efficient drug delivery and electricity generation. They are also trying to experiment these methods with other nanomaterials such as carbon nanotubes. Similar surface patterns can also be found in nature. This mechanism is found in the veins of banana leaves and on the surface of Nameeb desert beetles. Nature always has the answers to our problems if we have an eye to look and a heart to care for it.

Lokesh Narwani

EC, 5th Sem.

title.rendered: Shaping Ultra -fast Light Waves Using Nanopillars

content.rendered:
Light, we know it as the mysterious electromagnetic radiation that has kept mankind in wonder for hundreds of years. Although we have come a long way in our quest to demystify light, there are still many things to be discovered that can potentially change the future of mankind itself. Recently, many scientists have been working on ways to control various properties of light. Shaping the light pulses or controlling its properties is very important for applications using optical cords. To increase the functionalities of these high-speed optical circuits as well as extending its applications requires us to control more properties of the ultra-fast light waves. A group of researchers at the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) and the University of Maryland’s NanoCenter have developed a ground-breaking and efficient method of shaping the light waves to our needs.


Researchers achieved this by first depositing a layer of extremely thin silicon (few hundred nanometers) on glass, then with a protective material they covered an array of millions of minute squares of silicon. The team created millions of minute pillars by engraving the silicon surrounding each square. These nanopillars are the key to shaping the light waves precisely.


The ultra-thin device is an example of a meta-surface which is used to change the properties of light such as amplitude, phase and polarisation of the light wave. This is done by carefully designing the size, density, shape and distribution of the nanopillars, enabling simultaneous and independent tailoring of multiple properties with nanoscale precision. For manipulating phase and amplitude of each frequency component of an ultra-fast wave, they designed individual nanopillars for each constituent colour in the pulse and an integrated polariser assembled behind the device. The light wave slows down when travelling through a set of nanopillars compared to its speed in air and its phase is also delayed. The amount of phase change is determined by the size of the nanopillars whereas the light wave’s polarisation depends on the orientation of the nanopillars. The change in amplitude can be achieved by attaching a device called polariser at the back of silicon.

Alteration of amplitude, phase and polarisation of the light wave in a very supervised manner can be used to encode data. Several chemical and biological processes can be studied as well as modified by tuning fine changes to the nanopillars. For example, to increase or decrease the product of a chemical reaction, alterations in the incoming light waves can be made. Further development in the device may give researchers control over the time evolution of light pulses which can be used to create devices that measure light frequencies used in atomic clock and also to identify planets of distant stars. Thus, this new approach using nanopillars can take us a step further in discovering path-breaking applications using ultra-fast light waves.

Parth Patel

IT, 5th Sem.

Although we have come a long way in our quest to demystify light, there are still many things to be discovered that can potentially change the future of mankind itself. Recently, many scientists have been working […]

title.rendered: Shaping Ultra-fast Light Waves Using Nanopillars

content.rendered:
It wouldn’t be exaggerating to say that electrons rule our world, right? They have even made it to our textbooks. We have learned about electrons and holes in depth in our first-year courses. Now, a research team at The Ohio State University have discovered almost accidentally a material which shows dual roles as both electrons and holes holder.

The concept of dual-personality material wasn’t relevant until the new discovery. We know that electrons have negative charge and holes, which are basically the absence of electrons have a positive charge. Movement of electrons and holes lead to the material conducting electricity. Electrons can be manipulated to radiate or absorb energy. A material can act either as an electron-holder or a hole-holder, but not both. Thus, we need to add layers of different materials to balance the properties to create a practical material. The new material is a crystal (NaSn2As2) which effectively holds both electrons and holes eliminating the need to add multiple layers of different kinds of materials.

This new finding proves wrong the long existing dogma in science that a material can be either an electron or a hole holder, but not both. When a fellow researcher was measuring the properties of the crystal when he observed that the material sometimes acted as an electron-holder and sometimes as a hole-holder. He ran the experiments again and again as something like was not possible previously, but got the same results. The case wasn’t that the electrons became holes because that would be the same assembly of materials. This material when observed keeping one property in perspective looks as an electron-holder but when observed in another way, it looks as a hole-holder.

In the materials which are made by adding layers different materials, the energy travels less efficiently through the structure. This increases the probability of failure in a device made from that material. In the new material which consists of layers of crystals of the same material, the carriers behave as electrons when travelling within each layer but they behave as holes when travelling between two layers. The researchers have named this dual-ability property of the material as ‘goniopolarity’ which occurs due to the unique electronic structure of the material. They also believe that there might be other materials that exhibit this property but are yet to be discovered.

This material opens up the possibility of a whole array of unique devices to be created. It could also simplify the electronics which can lead to efficient systems that are less likely to break down. Since this material can potentially change the way our traditional transistors function, most of the electronics around us can possibly be engineered in a new and more effective way. This includes LEDs in televisions, computers and laptops, solar panels and even the light sensors in our smartphones. Thus, this material has the potential to bring about a revolution in the world of electronics.

Parth Patel

IT, 4th Sem.

Now, a research team at The Ohio State University have discovered almost accidentally a material which shows dual roles as both electrons […]

content.rendered:
What do you do to send an article from one place to another? Simply use the postal or courier services, right! But what if one had to transport something on a much smaller scale? Nanotechnology comes to the rescue here! Scientists at the Centre for Functional Nanomaterial (CFN) have wrapped a box of a different kind. By using a chemical synthesis method, they engineered hollow metallic nano-sized boxes with cube-shaped pores at the corners. They also demonstrated how these “Nano wrappers” take the job of a postman at nanoscale and can be used to carry and release DNA-coated nanoparticles in a controlled way.

In this research, DNA coated particles were embedded on the nano wrappers. When the DNA fibres contract, the nanoparticles become small enough to fit in the openings and enter the hollow cavity. The nanoparticles can then be sealed within the nano wrapper by decreasing the salt concentration. The scientists also established the transformation of nanocubes to nano wrappers through spectroscopy experiments. Oleg Gang, leader of the research team, compares the nano wrapper with a box of which only the exterior can be used and not the interior. Most nanoparticle synthesis methods used today, produce solid nanostructures. We need approaches to engineer the internal space of these structures. Compared to their solid counterparts, hollow nanostructures has different optical and chemical properties which can be used for a variety of applications.

But what is the use these nano wrappers? The use of nano wrappers in medicine offers some exciting possibilities.  It can be used to make repairs at the cellular level. The treatments that were once only possible by vaccinations can now be made possible by taking the drugs in the form of a pill. Nanoparticles made of polyethylene glycol-hydrophilic carbon clusters (PEG-HCC) can absorb free radicals at a much higher speed than the proteins used by our body for this purpose. This ability to absorb free radicals may reduce the harm that is caused by the discharge of free radicals after a brain injury. They are used for the treatment of many genetic diseases like cancer, Parkinson’s disease, Alzheimer’s etc.

The efficiency of this nanoparticles can be further increased by using the nano wrappers by achieving controlled release of the material. It can also be used for other areas where there is a requirement to release the material inside it in a controlled way. These nano wrappers can revolutionize the normal drug delivery system. However, they are made of gold-silver alloy, so they are bound to be costly. But the researchers are looking forward to replacing the gold-silver alloy with other bimetallic materials and assemble them into large-scale architectures. So, we may be using them in regular treatments very soon!

Maulik Gandhi

IT, 2nd Sem.

content.rendered:
It is often said that “Old is gold” and the statement is quite valid in many of the cases. A perfect example of this saying is an ancient technique which was used to create vibrant colours by heating metal. Researchers of Case Western Reserve University have found that a 3,000 years old metallurgy technique is actually one of the simplest examples of a metasurface. Metasurfaces are artificial surfaces with subwavelength features that provide unique electromagnetic properties. They have used these findings to create a nickel thin-film perfect light absorber.
Perfect light absorbers are materials that absorb more than 99% of a certain colour and have high-tech applications. Researchers have developed such absorbers by using simple-film with the right combination of oxide and the metallic substrate. They deposited 150nm of nickel or titanium on silicon and then heated the film for 20 to 40 minutes at 400 degree Celsius. This resulted in the formation of an oxide layer on it and it absorbed approximately 99.94% of red light. It can be tuned across other wavelengths by changing its thickness which is achieved by adjusting the duration of heat exposure. Perfect light absorption occurs on heated metal because of the phenomenon called total destructive interference. The light rays emerging from the oxide layer and the metal substrate come together in such a way that they negate other’s effects. The remaining light is absorbed by the metal substrate. Hence, perfect absorption is possible in a simple way.
Perfect light absorbers are used in making sensors, solar panels and creating anti-theft products. Materials with such properties can be used to protect devices from noise and interference caused by electromagnetic signals. Earlier, such surfaces were created using nanolithography processes of fabrication. Such processes are lengthy, costly and cannot be used at the industrial level. Hence, the simplicity and reproducibility of these thermally-painted metasurfaces prove to be a better alternative. Also, the oxide films produced by heating metal maintain their colours at all angles. This heat-induced colour can be used to make holograms to protect currency and metal products from theft. It is yet to be discovered if high-resolution patterns can be formed or not by growing multiple layers of metal oxide. In future, gas sensors can also be developed using these perfect light absorbers.

Nidhi Shah

CE, 4th Sem.

Researchers of Case Western Reserve University have found that a 3,000 years old metallurgy technique is […]

content.rendered:
Every electricity consuming device produces waste heat in one way or the other. Millions of such devices operate in the world resulting in loss of copious amounts of energy worldwide. Some of it could be utilized via the “Thermoelectric Effect”, i.e. converting heat flow from a hot device to a cold environment into electricity. To take advantage of this effect requires materials with oxymoronic properties of good electric conduction and bad thermal conduction. A class of materials with cage-like structures have proved to be promising, after demonstrating low thermal conductivity by non-conventional methods.
A team of scientists, from the Institute of Solid State Physics at the Vienna University of Technology, have created one such substance called Clathrate. “Clathrates are crystals with a very special structure”, says Professor Silke Bühler-Paschen, a member of the team. The crystal lattice structure of Clathrates is such that they form tiny cages in which individual atoms get trapped. These trapped atoms can oscillate back and forth in their “prison” cell, without affecting the rest of the crystal. Heat in matter is present in the form of vibrations of its atoms. As it is heated, the vibrations get increasingly intense until, at some point, the bonds between atoms break and matter changes its form, which is called the Melting Point in case of a solid. A heat wave propagates by two types of vibrations. If atoms are strongly bound together, the vibration of an atom will propogate to its neighbouring atoms and the heat wave will spread through the material. The stronger the bonds, the faster the wave resulting in a material of good thermal conductivity. However, if an atom is only very weakly bound to its neighbours, just like the atom sitting in the clathrate cage, then it is largely independent of the others and the heat wave is extremely slow.
Clathrates exhibit a special interaction between these two heat waves resulting in thermal insulation. A property of clathrate crystal cage is that an atom inside can only vibrate in one of two possible directions. When a heat wave hits the atom in the cage, it only changes the direction of the oscillation. This phenomenon, called “Kondo-like phonon scattering”, slows down the heat wave, resulting in a decreased heat conductivity. A phonon is a unit depicting the vibrational heat wave in a crystal lattice, hence the effect is called phonon scattering. So, even though Clathrates can conduct electricity, they are good thermal insulators.
Clathrates provide the exact properties of materials needed to use the thermoelectric effect on an industrial scale. Phonon Kondo systems transfer heat largely via low-frequency heat wave. Hence Clathrates may as well be promising intrinsic thermocrystals, for applications such as heat waveguides or thermal diodes in the emerging field of phononics.

Kaushal Rohit

CE, 6th Sem.

Some of it could be utilized via the “Thermoelectric Effect”, i.e. converting heat flow from a hot device to a cold environment into electricity. To […]

content.rendered:
How magical it would be if we can reduce the size and weight of a supporting member in a structure without compromising its strength! The researchers at the University of Pennsylvania’s School of Engineering and Applied Science, the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign and the University of Cambridge have made a significant breakthrough in overcoming the challenge of increasing the strength to weight ratio of regular material. Inspired by natural wood, the researchers have successfully built a nickel based cellular material called as metallic wood. It is made up of nanoscale pores, which increases its volume, thereby decreasing its density. However, it enhances the strength of the material.

The study was led by James Pikul, Assistant Professor in the Department of Mechanical Engineering and Applied Mechanics at Penn Engineering. Bill King and Paul Braun at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign and Vikram Deshpande at the University of Cambridge have been working for it.

A block of metal at its atomic level has a number of defects, which have occurred due to indefinite cooling, atmospheric conditions, various phase formations, etc. The material researchers have been studying the mechanical properties of the material taking these defects into consideration. The mechanical properties can be enhanced by decreasing the atomic defects at nanoscale level. By the modern technology of 3D printing nanoscale scaffoldings and pores can be obtained with higher levels of precision. The researchers have tested their theoretical calculations to prepare struts using metallic wood. The structs are of a dimension of 10 nanometers wide consisting of about 100 nickel atoms.

High porosity in wood supports the plant to transport energy. The scaffoldings and the empty pores with anode and cathode materials would work as a battery for aircrafts. The low density of the material and its high tensile strength finds its wide application in the field of aeronautical engineering. The metallic wood can serve the purpose of a prosthetic limb, as battery or as the wings of an airplane.

Currently the team is working towards producing the samples of metallic wood in larger sizes to study the macroscopic properties of material. The team is exploring the ways to introduce the new technology into other materials by introducing pores at its atomic level at the desired locations to decrease the density of the materials. The team aims to produce a material with 70 percent of void spaces but has high strength; these void spaces can be filled one day used as storehouses of energy in materials as well as in living organisms.

Nirmal Sunil

MH, 4th Sem.

content.rendered:
Most of us are familiar with the term thermoelectricity in one way or another. You might have also heard about a few thermoelectric materials capable of converting heat into electricity, but I am sure you haven’t heard of a material that is cultivated using bacteria. The material, “Thermoelectric paper” is a first of its kind which has achieved sustainability and is also recyclable. This new material was brought forward by the fellow researchers at the Institute of Materials Science of Barcelona (ICMAB-CSIC) and is basically composed of cellulose produced by the bacteria in an undisturbed environment in the laboratory.

The Bacteria produces nano-cellulose fibres when dispersed in an aqueous culture medium containing carbon nanotubes and sugar which forms the material in which the carbon nanotubes are embedded. The carbon nanotubes are responsible for the high conductivity of the material and nanocellulose facilitates its flexible, resistant and deformable nature. The researchers found carbon nanotubes to be more suitable because the diameter of the nanotubes is only a few microns in length, thus electrical percolation is possible i.e. it provides a continuous path for the electrical charges to travel through the material. About 10% of the amount in the material constitutes of carbon nanotubes which are perfect for maintaining high efficiency of the material making the process energy efficient and economical. As cellulose nanofibres and carbon nanotubes are more or less of the same size, homogeneous dispersion occurs making the material even more deformable, resistant and extensible.

The key aspect of the material is that it has high thermal stability allowing it to reach temperatures around 250° C. Moreover, the material is not made of toxic elements and cellulose can be recycled easily as it can be degraded by an enzymatic process converting it into glucose. Carbon nanotubes which are costly can also be recovered. Physical aspects of the material such as transparency, colour and thickness can also be controlled.

The devices made using the material could be used to generate electricity from residual heat to provide power to the sensors in the field of Internet of Things (IoT) used in Industry 4.0 and Agriculture 4.0 which are aided by recent technologies such as automation, IoT, cloud computing, cyber-physical systems, cognitive computing etc. They could also be used in wearable devices aiding the sports and medical industry in the near future. Due to high scalability of the process and flexibility of cellulose, devices using this material could be used in applications where the heat source has unusual forms or extensive areas, as they could be entirely covered with this material. This technology could be the beginning of the new shift in the way in which energy is produced as it has the future potential to enable users to create their own electrical generators.

Parth Patel

IT, 4th Sem.
